Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Staff Person 1 did not perform 15-minute eyes on check of
residents and then found Resident A unresponsive after a suicide Yes
attempt.
III. METHODOLOGY
01/31/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0219019
01/31/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
02/03/2020 Contact - Face to Face. Staff Person 1 interviewed with Detective
and video review.
03/06/2020 Contact - Face to Face. Therapist interviewed.
03/31/2020 Contact – Telephone call made. Security 1 interviewed.
04/01/2020 Contact – Telephone call made. Security 2 interviewed.
04/07/2020 Contact – Telephone call made. Staff Person 1 interviewed.
04/09/2020 Contact – Telephone call made. Security 1 interviewed.
04/30/2020 Exit Conference.
ALLEGATION: Staff Person 1 did not perform 15-minute eyes on check of
residents and then found Resident A unresponsive after a suicide attempt.
INVESTIGATION:
Incident report dated 01/30/2020 was reviewed. It states Resident A returning to
pod C and entering room 5 after his guardian visit at 06:24:33pm. At 06:59:21pm
Staff Person 1 opened Resident A’s door to prepare him for shower routine. Staff
Person 1 saw Resident A sitting on his bed with a sheet tied around his neck. Staff
Person 1 immediately called for help. At 07:00:43pm Facility Manager 1 and
Security 3 reported to the bedroom and began CPR. Security 1 arrived at
07:03:33pm with the defibrillator and emergency medical services arrived onsite on
07:19:35pm. Resident A is transported to hospital by EMS at 07:46:03pm.
2

Staff Person 1 was interviewed onsite by Police 1 and this writer on 02/03/2020 and
again via telephone on 04/07/2020. He stated being employed by the facility for
eight years and working the night of 01/30/2020 from 02:00-10:00pm. He stated pod
C is the isolation pod which contains residents who require separation from their
regular pod due to behavioral issues, medical needs, as well as suicidal residents.
Resident A was placed in the isolation pod because of behavioral issues he was
having with other residents on his permanent pod, and that Resident A was not
placed on the pod due to suicidal ideations. Staff Person1 stated entering the
dayroom area noting that Resident A had just returned from his visit and entered his
bedroom at 06:24pm. He reported staff were changing shifts and that one resident
was currently showering. He notes only one resident is to shower at a time and that
the remaining residents are to remain inside their bedrooms for safety reasons until
it is their turn to shower. Staff Person 1 reported when it was Resident A’s turn to
shower that he opened his door and that Resident A appeared fine. He reported
Resident A was sitting on his bed in an upright position though slumped forward
noting there was no indication that anything was wrong. Staff Person 1 stated
repeatedly calling for Resident A to get his attention in order to start his shower
though did not respond. He then stated entering Resident A’s bedroom and
observing Resident A with a bedsheet tied around his neck. Staff Person 1 stated
then contacting security personnel from inside the bedroom while attempting to untie
the bedsheet. He stated Security 1 arriving quickly and that when Resident A was
untied that he started do chest compressions. Staff Person1 stated other staff
entered the bedroom and that he left the area and proceeded to take the remaining
residents off the pod to the library. Staff Person 1 stated 15-minute bed checks are
not only for bedtime and are required for when residents are not in staffs direct
visual contact to include shower time.
Therapist 1 was interviewed onsite on 03/06/2020. She stated being employed with
the facility for two and a half years and has been Resident A’s therapist for the last
eight months. She last had a case conference and an individual therapy session
with Resident A on 01/28/2020, as well as a group therapy session on 01/27/2020.
Therapist 1 also indicates Resident A having a visit with his adoptive mother, just
prior to his suicide attempt, on 01/30/2020 from 06:00pm to 06:30pm. Therapist 1
stated, per adoptive mother, that Resident A had good conversation with her, that he
was planning on reunification, and appeared motivated. Therapist 1 stated Resident
A did not present with any suicidal ideation.
Therapist 1 also stated Resident A being placed on pod C, from pod J, for
approximately one week after daily programming as he was behaviorally aggressive
with other residents on the pod. She notes pod C has cameras inside each of the
resident bedrooms though states Resident A was not on suicide watch, as he did not
warrant it. Therapist 1 stated Resident A’s adoptive mother reported prior suicide
attempts while placed in her care. She also stated that adoptive mother and
Resident A’s prior and current probation officer believed that his prior suicidal
gestures appeared to be attention-seeking. Therapist 1 notes an incident at the
facility in 10/2019 which Resident A tied a shirt around his neck without any
3

planning. He was instructed to untie the shirt and consequently placed on suicide
watch on his pod and monitored every five minutes with follow up from his therapist.
She and Resident A’s current probation officer discussed the incident with him in
which he stated that he did not want to die, and that they discussed severity of his
actions in depth with him. Resident A continued to receive individual and group
therapy, as well as psychiatric services offered by the facility.
Security 1 was interviewed via telephone on 03/31/2020 and 04/09/2020. He stated
beginning his employment with the facility in 10/2019, attending the facility
orientation, and working the facility control board on 01/30/2020 for the 03:00-
11:00pm shift. He recalls Supervisor sitting at the control board at 07:00pm upon
arriving for his shift when the call came in regarding Resident A. Security 1 stated
he was most likely operating the control board prior to Supervisor arriving from
between 03:00pm until 07:00pm. He indicates that from the control room he can
observe all the hallways and pods, via security camera system, and can remotely
open doors throughout the facility. Pod C has cameras inside the bedrooms that
can be monitored from the control room for residents expressing suicidal ideations
and other problematic behaviors. He stated control room staff do not need to
continuously monitor suicidal residents on pod C as staff sit at the resident’s doors
and visually check on the them every five minutes. Security 1 stated the facility does
not have written policies or procedures regarding the operation of the control room
and that he learned the position through shadowing other staff. Since Resident A’s
suicide attempt control room staff are now required to monitor pod C’s bedrooms
hourly. Security 1 stated when residents cover a bedroom’s camera lens that he
would inform the acting supervisor on duty to clear the identified camera lens.
Security 1 stated he does not recall observing Resident A’s bedroom camera being
covered on 01/30/2020.
Security 2 was interviewed via telephone on 04/01/2020. She stated beginning her
employment with the facility on 01/15/2020, attending the facility orientation, and
working the morning shift on 01/30/2020. She notes shadowing other staff regarding
how to perform the functions of operating the control room and that there are no
written policy’s or procedures regarding the positions functions. She stated the
function of control room personnel is to observe hallways and open/close doors as
staff and residents move about the facility, as well as alerting security staff of issues
as they occur on the pods. She stated monitoring pod C’s bedrooms as well, though
stated staff on the pod do visual check of residents every 15 minutes during sleep
time and five-minute checks during suicide watch. She stated informing supervisors
when residents cover a bedroom camera. She stated cameras that are covered are
easy to identify on the monitors during the day though would be difficult to observe
at night.
Facility Director stated the facility does not have written policies or procedures
related to control room operations.
4

Video surveillance of pod C dated 01/30/2020 starting at 06:20pm was reviewed with
Detective. The following was observed:
06:20pm Staff Person 2 begins placing monitoring forms on each
bedroom door and handing each resident a hygiene box
before going inside their bedrooms.
06:24pm Resident A is escorted onto the pod by a security staff.
Resident A picks up his journal from the floor and proceeds
to walk into his bedroom and closes the door.
06:25pm Resident A places a privacy guard over the bottom portion of
his door window and the top is open.
06:26pm Staff Person 1 enters the pod and speaks with Staff Person
2.
06:27pm Staff Person 2 exits the pod and Staff Person 1 sits down
near Resident A’s bedroom door.
06:48pm Resident A takes down his privacy guard from his door
window and then puts it up again.
06:49 - 06:52pm Shadowed movements through Resident A’s privacy
guard are observed.
06:52pm Staff Person 1 walks to room #4.
06:54pm Staff Person 1 sits, and a large shadow is observed moving
through Resident A’s privacy guard.
06:59:02pm A resident comes out of shower and enters room #4.
06:59:21pm Staff Person 1 opens Resident A’s bedroom door.
07:00:24pm Staff Person 1 enters Resident A’s bedroom.
07:00:43pm Manager 1 and Security 3 enters Resident A’s bedroom.
07:03pm Additional staff enter Resident A’s bedroom with defibulator.
07:19pm Emergency services arrives.
Second video surveillance from inside room # 5 on pod C, dated 01/30/2020 at
03:46pm was reviewed. The following was observed:
5

03:46pm Resident A wets toilet paper and begins throwing it at the
camera lens positioned inside of his bedroom.
07:01pm Manager 1 removes wet toilet paper away from camera lens
07:01pm Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is being administered to
Resident A.
Resident A’s case record was reviewed and the following noted: Admitted on
02/07/2019, health assessment questionnaire notes attempted hanging in 2018,
12/29/2019 Youth health referral notes scratches to left arm from broom and denied
suicidal thoughts/intents. Suicidal precautions logging form dated 10/17/2019 notes
Resident A having tied a shirt around neck resulting in five-minute checks from staff
and follow up with therapist.
Staff-to-Resident Ratio policy was reviewed. It stated, “In order to provide for the
best care and welfare of the residents, at all times, the ratio of direct care workers to
residents, during normal waking hours, shall be no less than one worker to ten
residents. The normal staffing pattern will be two workers to eleven residents.
When residents are asleep, staff shall perform variable interval visual checks of
residents. The time interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes. This ratio shall
ensure the continual safety, protection, and direct care and supervision of the
residents.
The facility stated Resident A being currently placed with his adoptive mother after
placement in intensive care and then in rehabilitation. Resident A is speaking
though will require further occupational therapy. He is prescribed medications for
depression and nerve damage.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval
checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
6

ANALYSIS: Video surveillance shows that staff persons 1 did not perform
eye-on checks of residents every fifteen minutes as required.
Resident A enters the pod and then his bedroom at 06:24pm. It
is noted that programming requires residents to enter their
bedrooms at 06:30pm at which time individual showers begin.
Variable interval eye-on checks should have occurred on 06:39
and 06:54pm given Resident A’s entry into his bedroom at
06:24pm. Resident A is observed taking down his privacy guard
from his door window and then puts it up again at 06:48pm. It is
also noted that a shadow is observed behind Resident A’s
privacy guard at 06:54pm indicating his movement inside the
bedroom.
Staff Person 1 does not perform an eye-on check of resident A
until he opens Resident A’s door at 06:59pm. Staff Person 1
enters Resident A’s bedroom at 07:00pm to discover him sitting
on his bed slumped forward with a piece of bedsheet around his
neck.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Staff qualifications.
(1) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Staff Person 1 was trained and aware of licensing rules and
their duties regarding monitoring residents every 15-minutes
when not under direct supervision to include shower time and
when not sleeping. Failure to monitor the residents as
described per rule demonstrated an inability to perform the
duties of the position.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility does not have written policies and procedures
regarding the operation of the control room which monitors all
resident movement throughout the facility, including inside the
bedrooms on pod C. Per staff interviewed, video monitoring of
residents inside pod C bedrooms is not required, even for
residents on suicide watch, as staff on the pod are positioned
outside the resident’s door. Policies and procedures regarding
the use of the video monitoring system, to include inside the
bedrooms, must be developed regarding service delivery and
staff expectations.
Resident A placed wet toilet paper over the camera lens inside
his bedroom at 03:46pm and was not discovered and taken
down until 07:01pm. Security 1 states he did not recall
observing Resident A’s monitor being obstructed by toilet paper
and states if he had observed such blockage would have called
for supervisor assistance.
The facility’s written staff-to-resident ratio policy does not
address variable interval visual checks of residents when
outside of the direct supervision of staff during non-sleep times.
It is, however, noted that staff interviewed acknowledges 15-
minute bed checks of residents are not exclusive to sleep time.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an approved corrective action plan it is recommended that no
change to the current license be issued.
